question: History: Undiagnosed/uncontrolled Diabetes since 2003... rapid weight loss of 70 lbs. without tryingHypertension, Thyroid (right half removed - noduoes) Gestational diabetes, uncontrolled tremor on right side.Diagnosed with diabetes type 2, and uncontrolled tremor (non keotic chorea-ballism) attributed to high sugars in 2013 after CT/Mri showed 2 lesions in brain.  Along with tremor came occasional right side numbness/tingling of leg, arm, side of face, and back, foggy "out of it" feeling, resulting in getting to a chair fast or falling to the floor.  No loss of consciousness.Treated with Haldol to reduce tremor, diabetes medication (metformin), and monitored.  After about 2.5 mos. tremor resolved to occasional hand cupping and weakness.Symptoms above (numbness, tingling, falling) went away but are now back without the falls.  Right sided heavy foot feeling, difficulty walking, numbness/tingling of right side (leg, arm, face) came back and ER trip resulted in diagnosis of TIA.  MRI without contrast and with contrast showed no changes since 2013 incident.Today... total 24/7 numbness in both feet (neuropathy?) but no pain except occasional shooting/stabbing or burning sensations. Difficulty walking, feet feel heavy at times, sometimes one of both feet fall asleep while walking.  General weakness, fatigue, memory problems, confusion, and feeling of something not right.  At times numbness and tingling in leg, arm, and face come back... have taken blood sugar and blood pressure at these times and both are within normal range.Doc wants to take a wait and see attitude.  Suggests that the symptoms that she at first thought were related to the Diabetes are NOT and might be part of a neurological problem such as Parkinson's.  This is limiting the fun I should be having with my three year old!  I cannot walk for long distances, at times I  am having trouble driving (feeling where my foot is in space), not being able to feel whether foot is pressing down or not on gas/brake.Any help or suggestions would be appreciated!
title: Right side weakness...
